body.p:
I write you only to explain why I did not
write more fully when I send you a Sermon yesterday.
In frimis[?]–I had made up my mind not to send again
a single line, until I had heard from you, and I was
the more induced to determine this, since you did not
even acknowledge the receipt of my last when you
sent the Feby No of the Occident I acknowledge, I have
been somewhat amiss in not having sent you the
article I promised but this has arisen from an
unavoidable circumstance, viz. The necessity
of referring to a rather source work which it
is impossible for me to see in Canada and I
have been compelled therefore to write to england
about it. To make amends, I sent you a Sermon
and as I wished to send it you as early soon
after it was copied as possible, as I was told
at the Post Office that the American mail was
just about being closed I thought it better to
send it you on without delaying a day, as you
might then be able to insert it your next
number which I would like I therefore borrowed
a wafer at the Post Office, and before this reaches you,
you will have received it. If you can find room
and you think it worthy insertion, may I request
that you will have the goodness to attend to the

proper insertion of the notes, punctuation &c. and that
there [?] more mistakes in than escape your own
eye. You will perceive that in translating a quotation
from the Psalms. I have used Millan's beautiful version
which proceeding, if perhaps novel, I don't think
more objectionable than quoting the christian authorised
version. I have even used Lawth's, or Bro[?], version
when quoting the most sublime of the prophets. I think
that such version send much more than the authorised
translation to give us an ide I ought rather to say
to give those who dont read the original, an idea
of the force & beauty of the Hebrew texts. Let me
have your opinion. I must further say that
I dont forget them in fruits where they drag in
the [?] Jasus "as Pat calls him, whether
he has any right there or not, but recollecting this
even, Jeandices[?] that as they hear these quotations
from orthodox lifes[?] that there is no more danger
in using them than in using any English Bible
with their objectionable headings or New Testament
additions—muit ce'st apez Jour cela—To save
postage I have written the Sermon on thin paper and
[?] for the same reason I wrote the prayer
on a small piece of paper and I must ask you to
see that it comes in, in its proper place, it is
marked to age [?].
This prayer which as you

will perceive is nothing but a congeries of verses from
the Parasa & Sftora of the day I must request you to
alter. At the commencement instead of its reading and
hast turned their heart back again "please let it read
"who will turn their heart back again"–I am induced
to make this alteration because however I may
understand the [Hebrew] I dont like to oppose my opinion
to that [Hebrew] who in his [Hebrew] uses this
verse in proof of the correctness of the opinion of
the Rabbinni[?] thus "[Hebrew]—To his opinion
I may defer. I have much that I desire to communicate
with you upon, but I shall not do so until I
have heard from you the course of your long
silence, Have you any of Noga's[?] pamphlilets
Hebrew and English if you have let me have a copy
I sent some names [?] as subscribers but have
heard nothing from home concerning them–
are they in your parcel. My uncle the publisher
of "the Voice" wrote me he had sent me the nos "in
the American Israel[?]" Is that addressed to you or
to Mr Isaacs. I received a letter from him last
week but he says nothing about them. And now
dear friend, as I have purposely limited myself
to a small piece of paper, I must conclude & wishing
therefore the approaching days of Purim [Hebrew]
For the delivery of this I am indebted to
Mr Bernal, my [?]
correspondent, and friend of my family
how does he get on as [?] minister? What kind of a person
is he. Is he [?]? Personally I am quite unknown to him.
